Situation1: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: The register beeped as I scanned the last few items, my mind half on the numbers and half on my phone vibrating in my pocket. The end-of-shift tally was always tense—one wrong entry, and I’d be stuck here for hours, explaining every cent. My manager expected perfection, especially with the high-value transactions tonight. But as I handed a customer their change, a message flashed on my phone: “Police are blocking exits. We need you now.” My heart pounded. As an activist, I was supposed to help coordinate a safe response, make sure no one panicked or got hurt. But here I was, tied to the register, responsible for every dollar, with a line of customers waiting and my manager watching. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—one demanding precision and calm, the other urgent action and solidarity. My hands shook as I counted bills, torn between the duty to my job and the call to protect my friends.
